abstract.p: Robert P Weiss letter on Dick Thornburgh's Sept 20 Op-Ed column on corporate misconduct

block.p: Re ''Sue, but Don't Prosecute,'' by Dick Thornburgh (Op-Ed, Sept. 20): An important factor in the deterrence of corporate misconduct is the stigma of criminal conviction. Corporate violations have for too long been treated as civil wrongs, where a fine is considered the equivalent of a tax on misconduct. And with ''tort reform in states like Texas, an increasingly inconsequential ''tax'' is threatened -- a slap on the wrist.

Re ''Sue, but Don't Prosecute,'' by Dick Thornburgh (Op-Ed, Sept. 20): An important factor in the deterrence of corporate misconduct is the stigma of criminal conviction. Corporate violations have for too long been treated as civil wrongs, where a fine is considered the equivalent of a tax on misconduct. And with ''tort reform in states like Texas, an increasingly inconsequential ''tax'' is threatened -- a slap on the wrist.

If ever the fear of criminal stigma and the threat of imprisonment were deterrents to wrongful conduct, it would be in the case of white-collar crime, which is injurious behavior committed by people of high social status in the rational pursuit of maximizing profit.
ROBERT P. WEISS Plattsburgh, N.Y., Sept. 20, 2000
The writer is a professor of sociology and criminal justice, State University of New York at Plattsburgh.
